[{"front": "What conditions or injuries might be suggested by the presence of total hematuria?", "back": "Total hematuria, which is the presence of blood in the urine, can be suggestive of a number of conditions or injuries. One possibility is kidney damage, which may be caused by a variety of factors such as infection, trauma, or kidney stones. Another possibility is ureter damage, which is damage to the tubes that carry urine from the kidneys to the bladder. This can also be caused by a variety of factors, such as trauma or obstruction. Other conditions that may cause total hematuria include bladder cancer, prostate cancer, and urinary tract infections. It is important to seek medical attention if you experience total hematuria, as it can be a sign of a serious underlying condition."}, {"front": "In diabetic patients, what is the range of creatinine/albumin ratio that indicates the use of ACE inhibitors?", "back": "A creatinine/albumin ratio between 30-300 indicates the use of ACE inhibitors in diabetic patients."}, {"front": "What type of diarrhea does Vibrio cholerae cause, and what are the visible characteristics of the diarrhea?", "back": "Vibrio cholerae causes profuse watery diarrhea with visible flakes of mucous and epithelial cells. The diarrhea is a hallmark symptom of cholera and can lead to severe dehydration and electrolyte imbalances if left untreated. The visible flakes of mucous and epithelial cells are a result of the rapid turnover of cells in the lining of the small intestine, which is a characteristic of the disease."}, {"front": "What are the names of the macrolide antibiotics that are known to inhibit CYP450?", "back": "Clarithromycin and erythromycin are the two macrolide antibiotics that are known to inhibit CYP450. CYP450 is a group of enzymes that are responsible for metabolizing many drugs and other foreign substances in the body. Inhibition of CYP450 can lead to drug interactions and altered drug metabolism, which can affect the efficacy and safety of many medications. Clarithromycin and erythromycin are commonly used antibiotics that are known to inhibit CYP450, and they are often avoided or used with caution in patients who are taking other medications that are metabolized by CYP450 enzymes. Other macrolide antibiotics, such as azithromycin, are not known to inhibit CYP450 and may be preferred in patients who are taking multiple medications."}, {"front": "What is the definition of vertebral disc herniation and what are the structures involved in this condition?", "back": "Vertebral disc herniation is a condition characterized by herniation of the nucleus pulposus through the annulus fibrosus. The intervertebral discs are made up of a tough outer layer called the annulus fibrosus and a soft, gel-like inner layer called the nucleus pulposus. When the annulus fibrosus weakens or tears, the nucleus pulposus can protrude through the opening, causing a herniation. This can put pressure on nearby nerves, causing pain and other symptoms. The location and severity of the herniation can vary, and treatment options depend on the individual case."}, {"front": "Which teratogen is responsible for causing a smooth philtrum and thin upper lip in newborns?", "back": "The teratogen that is responsible for causing a smooth philtrum and thin upper lip in newborns is alcohol, which can lead to fetal alcohol syndrome."}, {"front": "What is the typical number of lesions that are present in patients with progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy?", "back": "Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is a rare and often fatal viral disease that affects the central nervous system. One of the key characteristics of this disease is the presence of multiple lesions. These lesions can be found in various parts of the brain and can cause a range of neurological symptoms, depending on their location and severity. The number of lesions that are present in patients with progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy can vary, but it is typically many rather than just one or a few. The lesions are caused by the JC virus, which attacks and destroys the cells that produce myelin in the brain, leading to the disruption of normal nerve function. The diagnosis of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is usually made based on clinical presentation and imaging studies such as MRI scans, which can reveal the characteristic pattern of multiple lesions in white matter."}, {"front": "Which surgical procedure involves the en bloc removal of the head/neck of the pancreas, proximal duodenum, and gallbladder?", "back": "The surgical procedure that involves the en bloc removal of the head/neck of the pancreas, proximal duodenum, and gallbladder is called the Whipple procedure."}]

[{"front": "What is the potential adverse effect of cytarabine?", "back": "Cytarabine can result in myelo-suppression (-cytopenias)."}, {"front": "What are the conditions under which reactivation of VZV occurs?", "back": "Reactivation of VZV can occur with stress, aging, or an immunocompromised state."}, {"front": "What medical condition is associated with a positive Murphy's sign, which is inspiratory arrest on right upper quadrant palpation due to pain?", "back": "Cholecystitis is the medical condition that is associated with a positive Murphy's sign, which is inspiratory arrest on right upper quadrant palpation due to pain."}, {"front": "What thyroid imbalance is associated with decreased heat production (cold intolerance) and decreased sweating?", "back": "Hypothyroidism presents with decreased heat production (cold intolerance) and decreased sweating."}, {"front": "What is the most common cause of cervical myelopathy in older adults?", "back": "The most common cause of cervical myelopathy in older adults is spondylosis."}, {"front": "What is the primary organ where ketogenesis occurs in the body?", "back": "Ketogenesis occurs primarily in the liver."}, {"front": "How will new bleeding on subdural bleeding \"acute on chronic\" appear on non-contrast CT scan?", "back": "New bleeding on subdural bleeding \"acute on chronic\" will appear as hyperdense areas on non-contrast CT."}, {"front": "Which deficiency of an enzyme involved in glycolysis is responsible for causing hemolytic anemia in newborns?", "back": "Hemolytic anemia in newborns is commonly caused by a deficiency of the enzyme pyruvate kinase, which is involved in the process of glycolysis."}, {"front": "How do glucocorticoids function as anti-inflammatory agents, and what is the specific mechanism by which they can inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3?", "back": "Glucocorticoids function as anti-inflammatory agents by inhibiting certain processes in the immune system. They can inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 by inhibiting the enzyme 5'-deiodinase."}, {"front": "What is sideroblastic anemia and what is one possible cause of it?", "back": "Sideroblastic anemia is a type of anemia where the body has a decreased ability to produce healthy red blood cells. One possible cause of sideroblastic anemia is lead poisoning. Lead can affect the production of heme, a component of hemoglobin, which can lead to the development of sideroblastic anemia. Other causes of sideroblastic anemia include genetic mutations and certain medications."}]

[{"front": "What is sterile pyuria?", "back": "Sterile pyuria is a medical condition characterized by the presence of pyuria, which is the presence of white blood cells (WBCs) in the urine, along with leukocyte esterase, but with a negative urine culture. In other words, there are no bacteria or other microorganisms present in the urine, but there are high levels of WBCs, which is a sign of inflammation or infection. Sterile pyuria can be caused by a variety of underlying conditions, including certain medications, autoimmune disorders, sexually transmitted infections, and kidney or bladder stones. It is important to identify and treat the underlying cause of sterile pyuria in order to prevent complications and promote optimal health."}, {"front": "How is Job syndrome inherited?", "back": "Job syndrome, also known as hyper-IgE syndrome, is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means that a person only needs to inherit one copy of the mutated gene (from one parent) to develop the disorder. If a parent has the mutated gene, there is a 50% chance that their offspring will inherit the disorder. The disorder affects the immune system, causing recurrent bacterial infections, skin problems, and other symptoms."}, {"front": "What chemotherapeutic drugs cross-link DNA at the guanine N-7?", "back": "Cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide are chemotherapeutic drugs that cross-link DNA at the guanine N-7."}, {"front": "How can the administration of certain medications lead to coronary steal syndrome and what are the consequences?", "back": "Coronary steal syndrome occurs when administration of coronary artery vasodilators such as adenosine and dipyridamole shunts blood towards well-perfused areas, increasing ischemia in post stenotic regions. This can lead to reduced blood flow and oxygen supply to the affected area, potentially causing ischemic injury or angina."}, {"front": "Which endocrine pathology may be induced by the use of carbamazepine?", "back": "The use of carbamazepine may induce SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion)."}, {"front": "What are the typical symptoms of chronic heart transplant rejection, and how does it usually present?", "back": "Chronic heart transplant rejection is a condition in which the body's immune system attacks and damages the transplanted heart over time. This can lead to a variety of symptoms, including fatigue, shortness of breath, chest pain, and swelling in the legs and feet. However, chronic heart transplant rejection is often asymptomatic in its early stages. Instead, it is typically diagnosed based on imaging studies that show accelerated atherosclerosis, or the buildup of plaque in the blood vessels that supply the transplanted heart. This can lead to a decreased blood flow to the heart and impaired heart function, which can ultimately lead to heart failure if left untreated. Treatment for chronic heart transplant rejection may involve medications to suppress the immune system and prevent further damage to the transplanted heart, as well as lifestyle changes to reduce the risk of complications."}, {"front": "In what position does laryngomalacia tend to improve?", "back": "Laryngomalacia is a condition that affects infants and young children, and can cause a range of symptoms such as inspiratory stridor, difficulty feeding, and poor weight gain. While laryngomalacia usually resolves on its own as the child grows and the tissues become more rigid, there are some measures that can be taken to help manage symptoms. One such measure is positioning the child in the prone position, or on their stomach, which can help to improve breathing and reduce the severity of symptoms. However, it is important to note that the prone position is not recommended for unsupervised sleep, as it can increase the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). Therefore, it is important to discuss any concerns about laryngomalacia and its management with a healthcare professional."}, {"front": "What is the required infective dose of Salmonella?", "back": "The required infective dose of Salmonella is large."}, {"front": "What type of dysfunction may be present in patients with multiple sclerosis due to involvement of the ANS?", "back": "Multiple sclerosis may present with bowel and bladder dysfunction due to involvement of the ANS."}, {"front": "What is orthostatic hypotension, and how can peripheral conversion of levodopa cause it?", "back": "Orthostatic hypotension is a condition in which a person's blood pressure drops significantly when they stand up from a sitting or lying position, leading to dizziness, lightheadedness, and even fainting. Peripheral conversion of levodopa, which is a medication used to treat Parkinson's disease, can cause this condition by reducing the amount of norepinephrine in the body. Norepinephrine is a hormone that helps regulate blood pressure, and when its levels are reduced, blood vessels may not constrict as they should, leading to a drop in blood pressure upon standing. Other medications, as well as certain medical conditions, can also cause orthostatic hypotension. Treatment may involve adjusting medications, increasing fluid and salt intake, and wearing compression stockings."}, {"front": "What is the role of thyroid hormone during the perinatal period?", "back": "During the perinatal period, thyroid hormone is essential for CNS maturation."}, {"front": "What is cough variant asthma, and how does it differ from other forms of asthma?", "back": "Cough variant asthma is a type of asthma in which the primary symptom is a persistent, dry cough. Unlike other forms of asthma, cough variant asthma may not include the classic wheezing or shortness of breath associated with asthma. However, it is still considered a type of asthma because the underlying cause is airway inflammation and hyperresponsiveness. Cough variant asthma can be difficult to diagnose, as the cough may be mistaken for other conditions such as postnasal drip or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Treatment for cough variant asthma typically involves the use of inhaled corticosteroids or bronchodilators to reduce inflammation and improve lung function."}, {"front": "What is the embryological origin of the liver and gallbladder?", "back": "The liver and gallbladder develop from the foregut.

During embryonic development, the foregut is one of the three primary germ layers that give rise to the various tissues and organs of the body. The foregut gives rise to a variety of structures, including the esophagus, stomach, pancreas, liver, and gallbladder.

The liver is a vital organ located in the upper right quadrant of the abdomen. It plays a crucial role in metabolism, producing bile to aid in digestion and detoxifying harmful substances in the blood. The gallbladder is a small organ located beneath the liver that stores and releases bile.

The liver and gallbladder develop from the foregut as a result of a process called hepatic diverticulum formation. During this process, a small outgrowth of endodermal cells from the foregut gives rise to the hepatic diverticulum, which then differentiates into the liver and gallbladder.

In summary, the liver and gallbladder are important organs that develop from the foregut during embryonic development."}, {"front": "What are the common clinical features of late-stage Fabry disease?", "back": "Late-stage Fabry disease is characterized by progressive renal failure and cardiovascular disease. Fabry disease is a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to break down a type of fat called globotriaosylceramide. This leads to the accumulation of this fat in various organs and tissues, causing damage over time. In the late stages of the disease, the kidneys and cardiovascular system are particularly affected, leading to a decline in kidney function and an increased risk of heart attack, stroke, and other cardiovascular complications. Treatment options for Fabry disease are limited, but early diagnosis and management can help to slow the progression of the disease and improve outcomes."}, {"front": "What is the relationship between Malassezia furfur (M. furfur) and the production of melanocyte damaging acids?", "back": "Malassezia furfur is a type of yeast that is commonly found on human skin. It has been shown to produce melanocyte damaging acids through the process of lipid degradation. This can lead to a range of skin conditions, including hyperpigmentation and hypopigmentation, as well as other dermatological symptoms. The exact mechanisms by which M. furfur affects melanocytes are not fully understood, but research in this area is ongoing. Understanding the role of M. furfur in skin health and disease is an important area of study for dermatologists and other medical professionals."}]

[{"front": "Which groups of people are most commonly affected by subdural hematoma?", "back": "Subdural hematoma is most commonly seen among elderly alcoholics and infants (shaken baby)."}, {"front": "Which animal species serves as the reservoir for Francisella tularensis?", "back": "Rabbits are the reservoir for Francisella tularensis.\n\nFrancisella tularensis is a type of bacteria that can cause tularemia, a potentially serious illness in humans. The bacteria is primarily found in animals, particularly rabbits, which serve as the reservoir for the bacteria. Humans can become infected through contact with infected animals or through the bites of infected ticks or deer flies. Understanding the role of rabbits as the reservoir for Francisella tularensis is important for developing strategies to prevent and control the spread of tularemia."}, {"front": "How does childhood insulin resistance affect the levels of free sex steroids in the body?", "back": "Childhood insulin resistance may lead to a decrease in sex hormone binding globulin, which is a protein that binds to sex hormones in the blood. As a result, there may be increased levels of free sex steroids in the body. This can have a number of effects on the body, including an increased risk of developing conditions such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which is characterized by high levels of androgens (male sex hormones) in women. It is important to manage insulin resistance through lifestyle changes, such as a healthy diet and regular exercise, in order to reduce the risk of developing these types of conditions."}, {"front": "What is the most sensitive finding that suggests blunt aortic trauma?", "back": "Mediastinal widening is the most sensitive finding that suggests blunt aortic trauma. Blunt aortic trauma is a serious condition that occurs when there is a tear in the aorta, the main artery that carries blood from the heart to the rest of the body, due to a blunt force injury. Mediastinal widening is a term used to describe an abnormal widening of the mediastinum, which is the space in the chest between the lungs that contains the heart, aorta, and other vital structures. In cases of blunt aortic trauma, the aorta may become enlarged and cause widening of the mediastinum, which can be seen on imaging studies such as a chest X-ray or CT scan. If you have been involved in a traumatic event and experience chest pain or other symptoms, it is important to seek medical attention immediately to rule out any serious conditions such as blunt aortic trauma."}]

[{"front": "To which class of drugs does ifosfamide belong?", "back": "Ifosfamide belongs to the class of drugs known as alkylating agents, which are cytotoxic chemotherapy drugs."}, {"front": "How many amniotic sacs and placentas (chorions) do dizygotic (\"fraternal\") twins typically have?", "back": "Dizygotic (\"fraternal\") twins typically have 2 separate amniotic sacs and 2 separate placentas (chorions). Dizygotic twins occur when two separate eggs are fertilized by two separate sperm, resulting in two separate embryos. Each embryo develops its own amniotic sac and placenta, which means that dizygotic twins have their own separate environment within the uterus. This is in contrast to monozygotic (\"identical\") twins, who develop from a single fertilized egg and may share an amniotic sac and placenta depending on when the embryo splits during development. The number of amniotic sacs and placentas in twins can have important implications for their health and development, and is typically assessed using ultrasound imaging during pregnancy."}, {"front": "Where do neurons of the ventral lateral nucleus (thalamus) synapse with upper motor neurons (UMNs)?", "back": "Neurons of the ventral lateral nucleus (thalamus) synapse with UMNs in the motor cortex, specifically the precentral gyrus."}, {"front": "What type of seizure is suggested by a blank stare, suspected ADHD, and no post-ictal confusion?", "back": "A seizure with a blank stare, suspected ADHD, and no post-ictal confusion is suggestive of an absence seizure."}, {"front": "What is the name of the enzyme that converts tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA), and what is the role of the cofactor in this reaction?", "back": "The enzyme responsible for converting tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) is called tyrosine hydroxylase. This enzyme requires a cofactor called tetrahydrobiopterin in order to function properly. Tetrahydrobiopterin is a type of molecule that helps to transfer electrons during the reaction, which is necessary for the conversion of tyrosine to DOPA. Tyrosine hydroxylase is an important enzyme in the synthesis of various neurotransmitters and hormones, and its activity can be regulated by a variety of factors, including stress, drugs, and disease states."}, {"front": "What are hypnozoites, and where in the body are they found in cases of Plasmodium vivax and ovale infection?", "back": "Hypnozoites are a dormant form of the malaria parasite that can remain in the liver for extended periods of time, potentially reactivating and causing relapses of the infection. In cases of Plasmodium vivax and ovale infection, hypnozoites are found specifically in hepatocytes, which are liver cells that play a key role in processing nutrients and toxins in the body. Understanding the biology of hypnozoites and their location in the body is important in developing effective strategies for preventing and treating malaria, particularly in areas where these species of Plasmodium are endemic."}, {"front": "What is the recommended management for children under 5 years old with vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) grades 1-3?", "back": "The recommended management for children under 5 years old with vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) grades 1-3 is prophylactic antibiotics."}, {"front": "During which months is Coxsackievirus infection commonly seen?", "back": "Coxsackievirus infection commonly occurs during the summer months."}, {"front": "What is the relationship between intracellular calcium and cardiac contractility?", "back": "There is a direct relationship between intracellular calcium and cardiac contractility. When the concentration of intracellular calcium increases, it enhances the contractility of the heart muscle, leading to increased cardiac output. This is because calcium ions play a critical role in the process of muscle contraction, including the contraction of the heart muscle. In the context of cardiac glycosides like digoxin, these drugs can cause increased intracellular calcium, which contributes to their ability to enhance cardiac contractility. However, it is important to note that too much intracellular calcium can have negative effects on cardiac function, leading to arrhythmias and other complications. Therefore, the balance of intracellular calcium is carefully regulated by the body."}, {"front": "What is the primary cause of pseudogout (CPPD)?", "back": "The primary cause of pseudogout (CPPD) is most commonly idiopathic."}, {"front": "In a patient with an elevated serum PTH/Ca2+ and a normal urine Ca2+/Cr clearance ratio (> 0.02), what is the likely diagnosis?", "back": "The likely diagnosis for the patient's laboratory findings is primary hyperparathyroidism. Primary hyperparathyroidism is a condition that occurs when there is an overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by one or more of the parathyroid glands. This can lead to elevated levels of calcium in the blood (hypercalcemia), which can be detected by an elevated serum PTH/Ca2+ ratio. In addition, the normal urine Ca2+/Cr clearance ratio (> 0.02) suggests that the kidneys are able to effectively clear calcium from the urine, which is consistent with primary hyperparathyroidism. Diagnosis may involve imaging studies, such as ultrasound or sestamibi scan, to locate the overactive parathyroid gland. Treatment may involve surgical removal of the affected gland or glands, as well as medications to manage calcium levels in the blood."}, {"front": "What is the cause of pneumonia that can lead to high fever and watery diarrhea in a smoker?", "back": "Legionnaires' disease is the cause of pneumonia that can cause a high fever with watery diarrhea in a smoker."}, {"front": "In what situations can anti-thyroid drug therapy alone be used to treat Graves disease?", "back": "Anti-thyroid drug therapy alone can be used to treat Graves disease in those with mild disease, pregnant women, or older patients with limited life expectancy."}]

[{"front": "In the Krebs cycle, which specific step results in the direct production of a molecule of GTP?", "back": "The conversion of Succinyl CoA to Succinate is the step in the Krebs cycle that directly produces a molecule of GTP. This step is also known as substrate-level phosphorylation, as it involves the transfer of a phosphate group from a substrate molecule (Succinyl CoA) to ADP, resulting in the formation of ATP or GTP. The GTP molecule produced in this step can be used directly as an energy source by the cell, or it can be converted to ATP through the action of the enzyme nucleoside diphosphate kinase. The Krebs cycle, also known as the citric acid cycle, is a series of chemical reactions that occur in the mitochondria of cells and is a key part of cellular respiration, which generates energy in the form of ATP."}]

[{"front": "What is the relationship between the brachial artery and the median nerve at the elbow, and how can supracondylar fractures of the humerus affect their function?", "back": "The brachial artery is a major blood vessel in the arm that is paired with the median nerve at the elbow. Supracondylar fractures of the humerus are fractures that occur just above the elbow joint and can displace anteromedially, which can put pressure on the brachial artery and the median nerve. This pressure can lead to a condition called a pulseless hand, in which the hand may have a weak or absent pulse due to reduced blood flow to the hand."}, {"front": "What symptom is associated with lytic bone metastases?", "back": "Lytic bone metastases are associated with hypercalcemia, which is a condition in which there is an abnormally high level of calcium in the blood. This occurs because the cancer cells in the bone release calcium into the bloodstream as they break down the bone tissue. Hypercalcemia can cause a variety of symptoms, including fatigue, weakness, nausea, constipation, confusion, and even coma in severe cases. It is important to monitor for hypercalcemia in patients with lytic bone metastases and to treat it promptly to prevent complications."}, {"front": "How does Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome typically present, and what is the name of the syndrome it is commonly associated with?", "back": "Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome classically presents as "locked in" syndrome."}, {"front": "What are the symptoms associated with hip rocking and crepitus, and what condition is typically associated with these symptoms?", "back": "Hip rocking producing crepitus, pain, and mobility issues are typically associated with a pelvic fracture. Pelvic fractures can occur as a result of trauma, such as a fall or car accident, and can cause severe pain and difficulty with mobility. In addition to hip rocking and crepitus, symptoms of a pelvic fracture may include swelling, bruising, and tenderness in the affected area. Treatment for a pelvic fracture may depend on the severity of the injury and may include immobilization, pain management, and surgery in some cases. Physical therapy may also be recommended to help improve mobility and function following a pelvic fracture."}, {"front": "How is prolonged post-operative ileus characterized?", "back": "Prolonged post-operative ileus is characterized by hypo-active bowel sounds. Ileus is a condition in which the normal contractions of the intestines (peristalsis) are reduced or absent, leading to a blockage of the bowel. It is a common complication after surgery and can cause abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, and vomiting. In most cases, ileus resolves within a few days after surgery, but in some cases, it can persist for a longer period of time, which is known as prolonged post-operative ileus. One of the key features of prolonged post-operative ileus is the presence of hypo-active bowel sounds, which indicates a decrease in intestinal motility. Treatment may involve medications to stimulate bowel function, such as prokinetic agents or laxatives, as well as careful monitoring of fluid and electrolyte balance."}, {"front": "What are two commonly used disinfectants that are not sporocidal?", "back": "Alcohol and chlorhexidine are two commonly used disinfectants that do not have sporocidal activity."}, {"front": "Which type of renal tubular acidosis (RTA) can be induced by the use of acetazolamide?", "back": "Type 2 (Proximal) RTA may be caused by acetazolamide."}, {"front": "Which type of hernias are located medial to the epigastric vessels?", "back": "Direct hernias are located medial to the epigastric vessels."}, {"front": "What type of crystals are present in synovial fluid in pseudogout, and how are they characterized?", "back": "Pseudogout is characterized by the presence of rhomboid-shaped crystals with weakly positive birefringence under polarized light in synovial fluid. These crystals are composed of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate and are responsible for the inflammation and pain associated with this type of arthritis. The appearance of the crystals under polarized light is a distinctive feature of pseudogout and can aid in the diagnosis and management of the condition."}, {"front": "From which organelle do the newly synthesized coronavirus viral proteins, nucleocapsid, and positive-sense progeny RNA bud from?", "back": "The newly synthesized coronavirus viral proteins, nucleocapsid, and positive-sense progeny RNA bud from the Golgi apparatus."}, {"front": "What is the prognosis for 'Triple-Negative' breast cancer, which is negative for ER, PR, and HER2/neu?", "back": "'Triple-Negative' breast cancer, which is negative for ER, PR, and HER2/neu, has a poor prognosis."}, {"front": "What is the behavior of a patient with a perforation, and why do they exhibit this behavior?", "back": "A patient with a perforation, which is a hole or tear in an organ or tissue, will often lay motionless in fear that any movement will slosh fluid around and aggravate pain. This behavior is due to the fact that movement can cause the fluid to move around and irritate the tissues surrounding the perforation, leading to increased pain and potentially worsening the injury. Perforations can occur in a variety of organs and tissues, such as the stomach, intestines, or bladder, and may be caused by a number of factors, including trauma, infection, or underlying medical conditions. Treatment for a perforation typically involves surgical repair or other interventions to address the underlying cause and prevent further damage or complications."}, {"front": "What disorder is suggested by high osteoclast bone resorption causing a disorder of bone remodeling?", "back": "High osteoclast bone resorption causing a disorder of bone remodeling is suggestive of Paget's disease. Paget's disease is a chronic disorder that affects the way bones are formed and broken down, leading to abnormal bone growth and remodeling. Osteoclasts are cells that break down bone tissue, and in Paget's disease, these cells are overactive, leading to excessive bone resorption. This can result in weakened bones, deformities, and other complications. Paget's disease can affect any bone in the body, but it most commonly affects the pelvis, spine, skull, and legs. Treatment for Paget's disease may involve medication to slow down bone resorption and promote bone growth, as well as management of any associated pain or complications."}, {"front": "What is the underlying mechanism of choledocholithiasis?", "back": "Choledocholithiasis is caused by an obstruction in the common bile duct (CBD) proximal to the pancreatic duct, which can lead to elevated biliary and liver enzymes.

Choledocholithiasis is a condition in which gallstones become lodged in the common bile duct, which carries bile from the liver to the small intestine. The exact cause of choledocholithiasis is not fully understood, but it is believed to be related to the formation and migration of gallstones.

Gallstones can form in the gallbladder and then migrate to the common bile duct, where they can become lodged and cause an obstruction. This obstruction can lead to a backup of bile in the liver and gallbladder, which can cause elevated levels of biliary and liver enzymes.

In addition, other factors such as inflammation of the pancreas or bile ducts, infection, and tumors can also cause choledocholithiasis.

Treatment for choledocholithiasis typically involves endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), which is a procedure that uses an endoscope to remove the gallstones from the common bile duct. In some cases, surgery may be necessary to remove the gallbladder and prevent further complications."}]

Without the activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase, the cell would not be able to efficiently generate ATP from glucose or other carbohydrates. The regulation of pyruvate dehydrogenase activity is complex and is controlled by a variety of factors, including the availability of substrates and the energy state of the cell."}, {"front": "What is the effect of the neurons of the striatum on the neurons of the globus pallidus internus in the direct basal ganglia pathway?", "back": "In the direct basal ganglia pathway, the neurons of the striatum lead to the inhibition of neurons of the globus pallidus internus."}, {"front": "What is serum sickness, and how does it affect the immune system?", "back": "Serum sickness is an immune complex disease that occurs when the body produces antibodies to foreign serum proteins. [{"front": "How are paramyxoviruses transmitted?", "back": "Paramyxoviruses are primarily transmitted through respiratory droplets. Paramyxoviruses can also be transmitted through contact with contaminated surfaces, although this is less common. The symptoms of paramyxovirus infections can vary depending on the specific virus, but can include fever, cough, sore throat, and respiratory distress. Some paramyxoviruses, such as measles and mumps, can also cause more serious complications, such as pneumonia, meningitis, and encephalitis. To prevent the spread of paramyxoviruses, it is important to practice good respiratory hygiene, such as covering the mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing, and washing hands frequently with soap and water. Vaccines are also available for some paramyxoviruses, such as measles and mumps, and are recommended for all children as part of routine immunization schedules."}, {"front": "What is characteristic of a chest X-ray in a patient with Coccidioidomycosis?", "back": "A chest X-ray in a patient with Coccidioidomycosis may show lesions or cavities in the lungs, even if the X-ray appears otherwise clear. It is important for women with atypical epithelial hyperplasia to undergo regular breast cancer screening and monitoring to detect any changes or abnormalities in the breast tissue. In some cases, surgical removal of the affected tissue may be recommended to reduce the risk of developing breast cancer."}, {"front": "Does Coronavirus have an envelope?", "back": "Yes, Coronavirus is enveloped. However, the specific treatment regimen may vary depending on the patient's medical history and individual risk factors."}, {"front": "What is the name of the nucleotide triphosphate that is used in the charging of tRNA?", "back": "ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate) is the nucleotide triphosphate that is used in the charging of tRNA. The process of charging tRNA involves the attachment of an amino acid to the tRNA molecule, which is catalyzed by a specific enzyme called aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase. This process requires energy in the form of ATP, which is hydrolyzed to ADP (Adenosine Diphosphate) and Pi (Inorganic Phosphate) during the charging reaction. Once charged, the tRNA molecule can deliver the amino acid to the ribosome during protein synthesis."}, {"front": "Which type of chromosome is frequently involved in a Robertsonian translocation?", "back": "Acrocentric chromosomes."}, {"front": "Which HLA subtype is linked to pernicious anemia?", "back": "DR5 is the HLA subtype associated with pernicious anemia."}, {"front": "What is the process by which tyrosine is converted to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA), and what enzyme is involved in this process along with its cofactor?", "back": "Tyrosine is an amino acid that can be converted to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) through a biochemical pathway that involves the enzyme tyrosine hydroxylase, which requires tetrahydrobiopterin as a cofactor. This conversion is an important step in the synthesis of various neurotransmitters and hormones, including dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. This is because the disease is caused by an ACTH-secreting tumor, usually located in the pituitary gland. [{"front": "What is the effect of calcitriol on PTH production by the parathyroid gland?", "back": "Calcitriol inhibits PTH production by the parathyroid gland. PTH (parathyroid hormone) is a hormone that regulates calcium and phosphate metabolism in the body. When calcium levels in the blood are low, PTH production is increased, which leads to the release of calcium from bone and the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. Calcitriol, which is the active form of vitamin D, can help to increase calcium levels in the blood by promoting the absorption of calcium from the intestine and the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. By inhibiting PTH production by the parathyroid gland, calcitriol can help to prevent excessive calcium release from bone, which can lead to osteoporosis and other bone disorders."}, {"front": "What is Pramlintide an analog of?", "back": "Pramlintide is an analog of amylin (islet amyloid polypeptide, IAPP). Amylin is a hormone that is produced by the pancreas along with insulin. It helps to regulate blood sugar levels by slowing down the rate at which food is absorbed from the stomach and by suppressing the release of glucagon, another hormone that can raise blood sugar levels. Pramlintide works in a similar way to amylin by mimicking its effects. It is used in combination with insulin to help control blood sugar levels in people with type 1 and type 2 diabetes who are not able to achieve adequate control with insulin alone. Pramlintide is administered as an injection before meals and is usually well-tolerated, although it can cause side effects such as nausea and vomiting."}, {"front": "Which disinfection or sterilization methods are not effective against spores?", "back": "Alcohols, Chlorhexidine, and Quaternary Amines are examples of disinfection or sterilization methods that are not sporicidal."}, {"front": "Which class of bacterial genetics inhibitors can be used for the treatment of anthrax?", "back": "Fluoroquinolones can be used as bacterial genetics inhibitors for the treatment of anthrax."}, {"front": "What is the direct correlation between the degree of advanced glycation end product (AGE) formation and serum levels of what?", "back": "The degree of advanced glycation end product (AGE) formation is directly correlated with serum levels of glucose."}, {"front": "What is a potential consequence of malrotation of the intestines?", "back": "Malrotation of the intestines can lead to acute torsion and volvulus of the intestines."}, {"front": "What is the name of the healthcare payment model in which patients pay for all expenses associated with a single incident of care with a single payment?", "back": "The healthcare payment model that involves patients paying for all expenses associated with a single incident of care with a single payment is called global payment. In global payment, patients pay a single fee for all of the services and expenses associated with a particular episode of care, such as a surgery or hospitalization. This payment model is intended to incentivize healthcare providers to provide high-quality, cost-effective care, as they are responsible for managing all of the expenses associated with the episode of care. Global payment is often used in accountable care organizations (ACOs) and other value-based care models, which focus on providing high-quality care at a lower cost. However, it can also create financial incentives for healthcare providers to withhold care or to provide lower-quality care, so it is important to monitor the quality of care provided under global payment."}, {"front": "What are the characteristic features of Pityriasis rosea lesions?", "back": "Pityriasis rosea lesions are typically multiple pink plaques with a collarette scale."}, {"front": "How do PDE-5 inhibitors such as sildenafil and tadalafil treat Erectile Dysfunction?", "back": "PDE-5 inhibitors (e.g. sildenafil, tadalafil) are indicated for Erectile Dysfunction by way of increasing blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis."}, {"front": "What are the two nuclei in the hypothalamus that mediate the secretion of GnRH?", "back": "The two nuclei in the hypothalamus that mediate the secretion of GnRH are the preoptic nucleus and the arcuate nucleus."}, {"front": "What medical condition is treated with Vitamin B3 (niacin)?", "back": "Vitamin B3 (niacin) is used to treat dyslipidemia, a condition characterized by abnormal levels of lipids (such as cholesterol and triglycerides) in the blood. Niacin is a water-soluble vitamin that plays a key role in various metabolic processes in the body, including the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. It is also used to lower the risk of cardiovascular disease in individuals with high cholesterol levels. Niacin can be obtained through the diet or through supplements. However, it is important to consult a healthcare professional before taking niacin supplements, as high doses can have adverse effects on the liver and other organs."}, {"front": "What is the association between the typical antipsychotic chlorpromazine and corneal deposits?", "back": "The typical antipsychotic chlorpromazine is associated with corneal deposits. Corneal deposits are a rare but well-known side effect of chlorpromazine therapy, and they can cause a variety of symptoms, including blurred vision, halos around lights, and sensitivity to light. The deposits are usually asymptomatic and do not require treatment, but in rare cases, they can cause corneal clouding and vision loss. Therefore, patients taking chlorpromazine should be monitored regularly for signs of corneal deposits, and alternative medications may be considered if the deposits become problematic."}, {"front": "What is the site of origin for JNAs?", "back": "JNAs arise at the sphenopalatine foramen."}, {"front": "What type of signaling mechanism does gastrin use to reach parietal cells in the stomach?", "back": "Gastrin uses the endocrine signaling mechanism to enter the systemic circulation and reach parietal cells in the stomach."}, {"front": "What is the initial sign of diabetic nephropathy?", "back": "Microalbuminuria, which is characterized by an albumin excretion rate of 30-300 mg/day, is often the first sign of diabetic nephropathy."}, {"front": "What is the active ingredient in Depo Provera?", "back": "The active ingredient in Depo Provera is medroxyprogesterone."}, {"front": "Which type of cancer is commonly treated with continuous leuprolide therapy?", "back": "Prostate carcinoma is the type of cancer that may be treated with continuous leuprolide."}, {"front": "Among the three types of viral genomes, which one is not infectious on its own?", "back": "The (-) RNA viral genome is not infectious by itself and requires a viral RNA polymerase to transcribe it into a (+) RNA strand before it can be translated into proteins."}, {"front": "What will a CSF analysis reveal in a person with Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome?", "back": "A CSF analysis in Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome will reveal albuminocytologic dissociation."}, {"front": "What is a transversion and how does it differ from other types of DNA mutations?", "back": "A transversion is a type of DNA mutation that involves the substitution of a purine nucleotide (adenine or guanine) with a pyrimidine nucleotide (cytosine or thymine), or vice versa. This differs from a transition mutation, which involves the substitution of a purine nucleotide with another purine nucleotide, or a pyrimidine nucleotide with another pyrimidine nucleotide. Transversions are generally considered to be more deleterious than transitions, as they can result in more significant changes to the amino acid sequence of a protein and may lead to more severe phenotypic effects. Transversions can be caused by a variety of factors, including exposure to mutagenic chemicals or radiation, errors during DNA replication, or spontaneous chemical reactions within the DNA molecule."}, {"front": "What is the spirochete shape, and can you provide some examples of bacteria that have this shape?", "back": "The spirochete shape is a distinctive spiral shape, and some examples of bacteria that have this shape include Treponema (syphilis), Borrelia (Lyme disease), and Leptospira (leptospirosis)."}, {"front": "What are some potential complications of primary myelofibrosis, and how do they arise?", "back": "Primary myelofibrosis can cause splenomegaly and splenic infarcts due to extramedullary hematopoiesis. Myelofibrosis is a rare type of blood cancer that affects the bone marrow, causing abnormal growth of fibrous tissue and scarring. This can lead to a decrease in the production of blood cells, including red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. In some cases, the body may attempt to compensate for this by producing blood cells outside of the bone marrow, a process known as extramedullary hematopoiesis. This can cause the spleen to become enlarged (splenomegaly) as it tries to filter and store these extra blood cells. However, the increased blood flow to the spleen can also increase the risk of blood clots, which can lead to splenic infarcts (tissue death) in some cases. Other potential complications of primary myelofibrosis include anemia, fatigue, and increased susceptibility to infections."}, {"front": "What proportion of total body water is made up of intracellular fluid?", "back": "Intracellular fluid makes up two-thirds of total body water. This fluid is found within the cells of the body and is essential for many cellular processes, including metabolism, protein synthesis, and waste removal. The remaining one-third of total body water is extracellular fluid, which includes the fluid found in the blood vessels, lymphatic system, and interstitial spaces between cells. Maintaining the balance of intracellular and extracellular fluids is important for overall health, and disruptions to this balance can lead to a range of health problems, including dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, and edema."}, {"front": "What are the classic symptoms of asthma and what lung sound is commonly associated with it?", "back": "The classic symptoms of asthma are episodic cough, dyspnea, and wheezing (lung sound)."}, {"front": "What is the mnemonic used to remember the main clinical features of antidepressant discontinuation syndrome?", "back": "The mnemonic used to remember the main clinical features of antidepressant discontinuation syndrome is FINISH."}]

Ascending cholangitis occurs when bacteria from the intestine travel up the bile ducts and infect the liver. This can cause symptoms such as fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice. Fetal distress is a condition where the baby's heart rate is abnormal, indicating that the baby may not be getting enough oxygen. Multiple gestation refers to a pregnancy with more than one fetus, such as twins or triplets. [{"front": "What is hydrocephalus and how does it affect the brain?", "back": "Hydrocephalus is a medical condition characterized by an increase in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) volume that causes ventricular dilation and may lead to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). CSF is a clear, colorless fluid that surrounds the brain and spinal cord, providing cushioning and nutrients. In hydrocephalus, the excess CSF puts pressure on the brain, which can lead to a variety of symptoms, including headaches, nausea, vomiting, and vision problems. In infants, hydrocephalus can cause the head to enlarge rapidly, while in adults, it can result in cognitive decline, difficulty walking, and urinary incontinence. Treatment for hydrocephalus typically involves surgical intervention to remove the excess fluid and restore normal CSF flow."}, {"front": "In the context of blunt thoracic trauma, what is suggested by the presence of irregular, nonlobular infiltrates?", "back": "Blunt thoracic trauma refers to injuries to the chest caused by a blunt force, such as a fall or a motor vehicle accident. Irregular, nonlobular infiltrates seen on imaging studies such as chest x-rays or CT scans are suggestive of pulmonary contusion. Other signs and symptoms of pulmonary contusion may include chest pain, coughing up blood, difficulty breathing, and low oxygen levels. Treatment for pulmonary contusion may involve supplemental oxygen, mechanical ventilation, pain management, and monitoring for complications such as pneumonia or respiratory failure."}, {"front": "What are some types of abscesses that Klebsiella can cause?", "back": "Klebsiella is a type of bacteria that can cause a range of infections, including abscesses. In addition to abscesses in the lungs, Klebsiella can also cause pyogenic abscesses in other parts of the body, such as the liver. Pyogenic abscesses are pockets of pus that form in response to infection, and they can cause a range of symptoms, including pain, swelling, and fever. Treatment typically involves the use of antibiotics to clear the infection, as well as drainage of the abscess if necessary. Preventing the spread of Klebsiella in healthcare settings is important to reduce the risk of these complications."}]

This can cause a range of symptoms, including shortness of breath, chest pain, confusion, and low oxygen levels in the blood (hypoxia). Symptoms of Cushing's syndrome may include hypertension (high blood pressure), hyperglycemia (high blood sugar), weight gain, muscle weakness, and mood changes. The ARPexposed is expressed as a percentage and represents the proportion of disease incidence in the exposed population that is attributable to the exposure. Histological examination of thyroid tissue from patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis may reveal the presence of chronic inflammation, which is characterized by the infiltration of immune cells into the thyroid tissue. They work by inhibiting an enzyme called HMG-CoA reductase, which is involved in the production of cholesterol in the liver. For multiparous women (those who have given birth before), second stage arrest of labor is defined as no fetal descent after pushing for more than 2 hours. This condition can occur due to a variety of factors, such as fetal malposition, maternal exhaustion, or inadequate contractions, and may require interventions such as assisted delivery (e.g. forceps or vacuum extraction) or cesarean section to safely deliver the baby."}, {"front": "In which organs do the sticky red blood cells of Plasmodium falciparum cause blockages in the blood vessels?", "back": "The sticky red blood cells of Plasmodium falciparum can cause blockages in the blood vessels of several organs, including the brain, lungs, and kidneys. Plasmodium falciparum is a species of parasite that causes the most severe form of malaria in humans. The parasite infects red blood cells and modifies their surface proteins, making them sticky and more likely to adhere to the walls of blood vessels. This can lead to the formation of clumps of infected cells that obstruct blood flow and cause damage to the affected organs. Prevention efforts focus on controlling mosquito populations and reducing exposure to mosquito bites through the use of insecticide-treated bed nets and other measures."}, {"front": "What vaccine should be given to patients with HIV before starting ART?", "back": "Patients with HIV should be given the inactivated/killed influenza vaccine before starting ART. [{"front": "What are the sensory organs used by the inverse muscle stretch reflex to monitor muscle tension?", "back": "The inverse muscle stretch reflex uses Golgi tendon organs to monitor muscle tension."}, {"front": "What is the probable cause of kidney disease characterized by arteriosclerotic lesions of renal arterioles?", "back": "The likely underlying etiology of kidney disease with arteriosclerotic lesions of renal arterioles is hypertension. Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is a common condition that can lead to damage to various organs in the body, including the kidneys. In prokaryotes, DNA polymerase III is the primary enzyme responsible for DNA replication. It is a complex enzyme that consists of several subunits, each with a specific function. One of these subunits, the polymerase subunit, is responsible for the elongation of the DNA strand.

During DNA replication, DNA polymerase III adds nucleotides to the 3' end of the RNA primer synthesized by primase. It continues to add nucleotides in a 5' to 3' direction until it reaches the end of the template strand or encounters an obstacle, such as a damaged DNA base or a protein bound to the DNA.

This can cause fluid to leak out of the blood vessels and accumulate in the tissues, leading to peripheral edema. These symptoms can vary in severity depending on the degree of slippage and the duration of the condition. This decrease in the pleural space causes an increase in the intrapleural pressure, making it less negative relative to atmosphere. One important type of receptor in this system is the lung stretch receptor, which is a mechanoreceptor located in the smooth muscle of the airways. These receptors respond to changes in lung volume and pressure, and help to regulate breathing rate and depth. Lung stretch receptors are critical for maintaining the balance between ventilation and perfusion in the lungs, and play an important role in respiratory physiology and pathophysiology. Ventilation refers to the amount of air that reaches the alveoli (tiny air sacs in the lungs), while perfusion refers to the amount of blood flow to the alveoli. When the V/Q ratio is 1, it means that the amount of air reaching the alveoli is equal to the amount of blood flow to the alveoli, which facilitates efficient gas exchange. However, in some lung diseases, such as pulmonary embolism or emphysema, the V/Q ratio may be disrupted, leading to impaired gas exchange and potentially life-threatening complications."}, {"front": "What is the post-central gyrus and where is it located in the brain?", "back": "The post-central gyrus is a region of the primary somatosensory cortex that is located in the parietal lobe of the brain."}, {"front": "When is aspirin given in relation to tPA for MI?", "back": "Aspirin is typically given before tPA for MI. [{"front": "What is the relationship between hyperemesis gravidarum and metabolic alkalosis?", "back": "Hyperemesis gravidarum is a condition of severe nausea and vomiting during pregnancy that can lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. Metabolic alkalosis can be a serious complication of hyperemesis gravidarum and may require medical intervention to correct. Treatment for hyperemesis gravidarum may include medication, intravenous fluids, and other supportive measures to manage symptoms and prevent complications such as metabolic alkalosis."}]

LDL is often referred to as \"bad\" cholesterol, as high levels of LDL are associated with an increased risk of heart disease and stroke. [{"front": "What are the clinical features of pneumonia?", "back": "Pneumonia is a respiratory infection that can cause inflammation in the lungs, leading to a range of symptoms. The clinical features of pneumonia include a productive cough, which means coughing up mucus or phlegm from the lungs. The sputum produced during pneumonia may be yellow-green or rusty-colored, which is due to the presence of pus and blood, respectively. Other symptoms of pneumonia may include fever, chills, chest pain, shortness of breath, fatigue, and muscle aches. Treatment for pneumonia typically involves antibiotics to fight the infection, as well as supportive care such as rest, fluids, and over-the-counter medications to manage symptoms. It is important for individuals with pneumonia to receive prompt medical treatment to prevent complications and speed up recovery."}, {"front": "What are phasic contractions of GI smooth muscle and how do they occur?", "back": "Phasic contractions of GI smooth muscle refer to the periodic contractions and subsequent relaxation of the muscles that line the gastrointestinal tract. These contractions help to move food and other materials through the digestive system, and are an important part of the process of digestion. Unlike tonic contractions, which are sustained contractions that help to maintain tone in the muscles, phasic contractions occur in a rhythmic pattern that is controlled by a complex interplay of neural, hormonal, and local factors. While they are generally considered to be a normal and healthy part of digestive function, there are certain conditions that can cause phasic contractions to become irregular or excessive, which can lead to symptoms such as abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea."}, {"front": "What are some of the skin-related symptoms that can be associated with Primary biliary cholangitis?", "back": "Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects the liver and bile ducts, but it can also cause a range of skin-related symptoms. These skin-related symptoms can be distressing and can impact a person's quality of life, so it is important to work closely with a healthcare provider to manage them effectively."}, {"front": "", "back": ""}, {"front": "What is the first stage of labor and when does it start and end?", "back": "The first stage of labor starts from the onset of labor and ends when the cervix is completely dilated."}, {"front": "What is transcortical mixed aphasia and how is it related to damage around the watershed areas surrounding Broca and Wernicke areas and the arcuate fasciculus?", "back": "Transcortical mixed aphasia is a type of aphasia that is caused by damage to the watershed areas surrounding (but not including) Broca and Wernicke areas, as well as the arcuate fasciculus. This can result in difficulty with both expressive and receptive language, as well as difficulty with repetition. However, the ability to understand single words and perform automatic speech is preserved."}, {"front": "What are the initial treatment options for patients with asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic SIADH?", "back": "The initial treatment options for patients with asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic SIADH include fluid restriction and, in some cases, salt tablets. SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) is a condition that occurs when the body produces too much antidiuretic hormone, leading to an imbalance of fluids and electrolytes. This can cause symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, headaches, and confusion. The primary goal of treatment is to restore the balance of fluids and electrolytes in the body. Fluid restriction is a common initial treatment option, as it helps to reduce the amount of water in the body and restore the balance of fluids. In some cases, salt tablets may also be recommended, as they can help to increase the amount of sodium in the body and restore the balance of electrolytes. Other treatment options may include medications or addressing the underlying cause of the condition. Treatment should be managed by a healthcare professional with expertise in managing SIADH."}, {"front": "What is the induration size threshold for a positive PPD test in individuals with a high risk of tuberculosis (TB)?", "back": "In individuals with a high risk of TB, such as HIV-positive patients, immunosuppressed patients, or recent contacts of a known TB case, a PPD test is considered positive if the induration size is greater than 5 mm. Induration refers to the raised, hardened area around the injection site that is measured to determine the test result. In contrast, for individuals with a lower risk of TB, such as healthcare workers or individuals from countries with a low TB prevalence, a PPD test is considered positive if the induration size is greater than 10 mm. The interpretation of PPD test results must take into account the individual's risk factors, medical history, and other diagnostic tests, as false-positive and false-negative results can occur."}, {"front": "What is chronic renal disease, and how can this condition lead to the development of a secondary hyperparathyroidism syndrome known as Renal Osteodystrophy, which is characterized by bone lesions due to increased bone resorption (from elevated PTH)?", "back": "Chronic renal disease is a condition that occurs when the kidneys are not able to function properly, leading to a range of symptoms and complications. One of the potential complications of chronic renal disease is the development of a secondary hyperparathyroidism syndrome known as Renal Osteodystrophy. This condition is characterized by bone lesions due to increased bone resorption (from elevated PTH). The kidneys play an important role in regulating the levels of calcium and phosphorus in the body, and when they are not functioning properly, this can lead to imbalances in these minerals. This can in turn lead to the development of Renal Osteodystrophy, as the body attempts to compensate for these imbalances by increasing the production of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which can cause the bones to release calcium into the bloodstream. It is important for individuals with chronic renal disease to receive appropriate medical care and monitoring in order to prevent the development of Renal Osteodystrophy and other complications."}, {"front": "At which specific location are sister chromatids joined together at the end of S phase?", "back": "Sister chromatids are joined together at the end of S phase at the centromere."}, {"front": "Where is light focused in myopia (nearsightedness)?", "back": "In myopia (nearsightedness), light is focused in front of the retina."}, {"front": "What is fat necrosis of the breast, and what are some of the common clinical features associated with this condition?", "back": "Fat necrosis of the breast is a benign condition that occurs when there is damage to the fatty tissue in the breast. This can result in the formation of an ill-defined, firm breast mass with overlying skin thickening or retraction. Other symptoms of fat necrosis of the breast may include breast pain, nipple discharge, or skin discoloration. Fat necrosis of the breast is often diagnosed through imaging tests, such as mammography or ultrasound, and typically does not require any treatment unless it is causing significant discomfort or cosmetic concerns."}, {"front": "What is the first-line treatment for Group B Streptococcus (GBS) during labor and delivery?", "back": "Ampicillin or penicillin is the first-line treatment for Group B Streptococcus (GBS) during labor and delivery."}, {"front": "What is the increased risk associated with immobilization, cardiac wall dysfunction (arrhythmia, MI), and aneurysm due to disruption of blood flow?", "back": "Immobilization, cardiac wall dysfunction (arrhythmia, MI), and aneurysm increase the risk of thrombosis due to disruption of blood flow. Thrombosis occurs when blood clots form in the veins or arteries, which can obstruct blood flow and cause serious complications, such as pulmonary embolism or stroke. Immobilization, such as prolonged bed rest or long flights, can lead to blood clots in the legs, known as deep vein thrombosis. Similarly, cardiac wall dysfunction, such as arrhythmia or myocardial infarction (MI), can disrupt blood flow and increase the risk of thrombosis. Aneurysm, which is a bulge in the wall of a blood vessel, can also increase the risk of thrombosis if the blood flow is disrupted or if a blood clot forms within the aneurysm. It is important to be aware of these risk factors and to take steps to prevent thrombosis, such as staying active, maintaining a healthy weight, and seeking medical attention if you experience any symptoms of a blood clot."}, {"front": "How do macrolides work to inhibit bacterial protein synthesis?", "back": "Macrolides work by binding to the bacterial 23s rRNA of the 50s subunit of the ribosome, which blocks the amino-acyl transpeptidation and translocation steps of protein synthesis. This prevents the ribosome from adding new amino acids to the growing peptide chain, effectively inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis. Macrolides are bacteriostatic, which means they prevent the growth and replication of bacteria, rather than killing them outright. Because they target a specific step in the protein synthesis process, macrolides are effective against a wide range of bacterial infections, including respiratory tract infections, skin infections, and sexually transmitted infections. However, it is important to note that overuse and misuse of antibiotics, including macrolides, can contribute to the development of antibiotic resistance in bacteria."}, {"front": "What genetic mutation is associated with overexpression of Bcl 2 and Bcl 6 in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma?", "back": "The genetic mutation associated with overexpression of Bcl 2 and Bcl 6 in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma is t(14;18), which is a translocation between chromosomes 14 and 18. This translocation results in the deregulation of the Bcl 2 gene, which normally regulates programmed cell death (apoptosis), leading to increased survival of B cells. Additionally, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma can also be associated with mutations in the Bcl 6 gene, which plays a role in regulating DNA transcription. These genetic alterations contribute to the uncontrolled growth and proliferation of B cells, leading to the development of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma."}, {"front": "Which medication is associated with low suicide risk in individuals with schizophrenia?", "back": "The medication associated with low suicide risk in individuals with schizophrenia is clozapine. Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic medication that is often used in the treatment of schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders. It has been shown to be particularly effective in reducing symptoms such as hallucinations and delusions, and has also been associated with a lower risk of suicide compared to other antipsychotic medications. This is thought to be due in part to its ability to reduce aggression and impulsivity, as well as its effects on certain neurotransmitters in the brain. While clozapine can have some side effects, including weight gain and sedation, it is generally considered to be a safe and effective treatment option for individuals with schizophrenia who are at risk of suicide."}, {"front": "What are the three major causes of acute arterial occlusion?", "back": "The three major causes of acute arterial occlusion are embolus from a cardiac or arterial source, arterial thrombosis, and iatrogenic/direct blunt trauma to the artery."}, {"front": "What does the presence of intraplacental villous lakes on ultrasound suggest in a pregnant patient?", "back": "In a pregnant patient, the presence of intraplacental villous lakes on ultrasound is suggestive of placenta accreta. Placenta accreta is a condition where the placenta attaches too deeply into the uterine wall, and it can lead to complications during delivery such as heavy bleeding and the need for a hysterectomy. Intraplacental villous lakes are cystic spaces within the placenta that are filled with maternal blood, and their presence on ultrasound can indicate abnormal placental development. Therefore, if intraplacental villous lakes are detected on ultrasound during pregnancy, further evaluation and management by a healthcare provider is necessary to assess for the possibility of placenta accreta and other potential complications."}, {"front": "What are the three phases of the bacterial growth curve?", "back": "The three phases of the bacterial growth curve are the lag phase, the growth/log phase, and the stationary phase."}, {"front": "What is the relationship between cord prolapse and fetal presentation?", "back": "Cord prolapse often occurs with abnormal fetal presentation."}]
